Dr. Robert Lincoln Slagle,
awarded a Doctor of Philosophy degree at Johns Hopkins
in 1894, has resigned the presidency of the University of
South Dakota. The resignation is to take effect in September, 1929.
For 14 years Dr. Slagle has
been president of the Western
university. He was graduated
from Lafayette College in
1887, studied here from 1889
to 1892, and again in 1893-4,
and was subsequently professor of chemistry at the School
of Mines.

Dunlap Says Mouth
Is Most Expressive
A girl's mouth, and not her eyes,
will reveal the depth of her feelings,
romantic tradition notwithstanding,
according to the discoveries of Dr.
Knight Dunlap, professor of Psychology here, in the field of facial
expression.
Dr. Dunlap, by taking pictures
representing the usual emotions registered by the human countenance,
and cutting them so as to separate
the eyes from the nose and mouth,
was able to piece them together in
such a way that the eyes, supposed
to indlcte one feeling, readily
seemed to express another when
matched with a second mouth. The
mouth muscles remained the indices
to the emotions.

DR. LANCASTER PRESENTS FIRST OF
TEN VOLUMES ON FRENCH LITERATURE
Dr. H. Carrington Lancaster, professor of French Literature and
chairman of the Department of Romance Languages, announced that
the Johns Hopkins Press will publish the first two volumes of his latest work: "A History of French
Dramatic Literature in the Seventeenth Century." The set of books
in its entirety will comprise, Dr.
Lancaster said, probably ten volumes.
The first two volumes will have
the sub-title "The Pre-Classical
Period (1610-1634)," and although
they are in the process of being
printed, will not make their appearance before the beginning of the fall
term.

reign of Henry IV.
The book will be used by graduate
students and professors and is expected to provide an instructive
treatise upon the subject.

TRIP FRUITFUL
Musical Club Members Accorded

PERFORMANCES IMPROVING
Club Performs Before Audiences
at Easton and Salisbury
Acclaimed by enthusiastic audiences in Easton and .Salisbury, the
Musical Club, on December 26 and
27, made a big success of its annual
Eastern Shore tour. Noticeable improvement in the quality of the
organization's performance marked
both concerts.
Accompanied by Mr. Conrad
Gebelein, director of the Banjo
Club, about 50 members left Homewood on Monday at 9 A. M. on two
buses and arrived in Salisbury at
3 p. m., having taken lunch en route
at Dover. At Salisbury the club occupied an entire floor of the Wicomico Hotel. The men were entertained in the afternoon at a tea
given by Mrs. Ruark and Mrs. Atkins, and a number were entertained
afterwards by friends.
Boynton on Vacation

I. Evans Rodgers was substituted
for Benny Boynton, who was home
on vacation. The former Barnstormer president was well received.
The Banjo Club was also particularly impressive in the presentation
at the Arcade Theater. The concert
was well attended, and the dance,
held afterwards at the hotel for the
benefit of a local hospital, was
crowded.
Tuesday, at 4 P. M., the club left
for Easton, and went directly to the
theater. Here the audience was not
only large, but very sympathetic.
The performance was benefited by
the previous night's experience; the
entire program received a more effective rendition. Particularly was
this noticed in the work of the Hawaiian group, which made a big
hit
with two additional numbers.

"The Student and the Social
Order" served as the general subject of the annual meeting of the
League of Industrial Democracy,
held at Columbia University, December 28-30.
The conference opened with a
symposium on -Present-day Capitalism in America," several prominent American economists taking
part. Sessions on the following day
were confined to informal discussion
groups on "Liberal Activities on the
Campus," "Education as a Road to
Freedom," "The Value of Political
Action" and "The Class Struggle
and Labor Unionism."
Among the prominent figures attending the league sessions were:
Ivy Lee, Prof. Harry F. Ward, Paul
Blonshard, Robert Morse Lovett,
William P. Hapgood, Norman
Thomas, Felix Cohen, United States
Senator Gerald P. Nye, Norman
Hapgood and Dr. Harry W. Laidler.

America Discovered for $7200
Old records show that the cost of Columbus' first
expedition to America amounted,in modern exchange,
to only $7200. To finance Columbus, Isabella,
Queen of Spain, offered to pawn her jewels. Today
word comes from Spain indicating that a twentieth
century importation from the new world is fast effecting a sufficient saving to ransom many royal jewels.
The Spanish Northern Railway reports that the
American equipment with which in 1924 the railroad
electrified a mountainous section of its lines from Ujo
to Pajares has accomplished the following economies:

The substations, overhead
equipment for the complete

installation, and six of the
twelve locomotives for this
particularly difficult and
successful electrification
were furnished by the General Electric Company. General Electric quality has
attained universal recognition; the world over, you
will find the G-E monogram
on apparatus that is giving
outstanding service.

1. A 55% saving in the cost of power.
2. A reduction of 40% in the number of engine miles for
the same traffic handled.
3. A saving of 7332% in the cost of repairs and upkeep
for locomotives.
4. A saving of 63% in crew expenses.
5. A reduction of 31% in the cost of moving a tonkilometer of freight.

In every part of the world, electricity has replaced
less efficient methods and is saving sums far
greater than the ransom of a queen's jewels. Xou
will always find it an important advantage in your
work and in your home.

When the "New Plan" was announced as the definite policy
of this University, one of the revolutionary features of the
plan was the abandonment, in the near future, of the first two
years of collegiate instruction and the abolishment of the
College of Arts and Sciences. The student body would be
composed of only those students who sought a higher degree
than the Bachelor of Arts.
For various reasons, since the first enunciation of the plan,
the apparently fairly imminent abolition of the College of Arts
and Sciences has been placed in the category of an "ultimate
end." And more recently it has become more and more apparent that this part of the plan cannot become a reality for years
to come. Hopkins needs the undergraduate department. It is
hardly heresy to say, particularly, that the University needs
the income derived from the undergraduates' tuition fees.
This is an undisputed fact. Of course, it is conceivable that
some wealthy man or institution such as the General Educational Board might suddenly present the University with a
few million dollars, but we shall let you draw your own conclusions as to the probability of this..
For the past year the University has centered its attention
upon the New Plan. The undergraduate department has received little notice and considerable neglect. The list of courses
has been drastically cut, and many students are being subjected to high school pedagogical methods at the hands of
earnest and well-meaning, but green, student assistants.
The unfortunate situation that now exists was almost inevitable, however. The past year has been one of transition and
experiment, one in which the undergraduate department was
bound to suffer. The censure that has been passed upon the
administration by many of the students should, more rightfully, have been cast upon the existing circumstances.
Many members of the faculty realize that the College of
Arts and Sciences canot be abolished for some time to come.
They realize, moreover, that if this is the case, the undergraduates are deserving of more consideration than the catalogue accords them at present. Before the end of the year, we
have good reason to believe, several changes will take place
that will grant to the students in the College a wider range of
courses and a more satisfactory working basis generally. In
place of the two or three courses now being offered in any one
department, it is quite probable that a system will be inaugurated wherein five or six courses will be given, although in
alternate years. Such a plan would allow the departments
to keep within their budgets, but at the same time would
allow students to take more than two courses in any subject.
It is undoubtedly an improvement over the present scheme of
starvation.
Unless we are very much mistaken, the College next year
should be a much more satisfactory place to attend than it has
been so far this year. We do not strike this note of optimism
with any misgivings: We believe that the administration
realizes that certain conditions are unsatisfactory, and will
take steps, shortly, to remedy them.

represented the international -students. Edward Cunningham and
Chester Lawson attended from the
School. Representing the

ihompson and Miss Margaret
Craig. Mr. and Mrs. E. A. Schaal
were the secretarial delegates.

Dr. Robert Lincoln Slagle,
awarded a Doctor of Philosophy degree at Johns Hopkins
in 1894, has resigned the presidency of the University of
South Dakota. The resignation is to take effect in September, 1929.
For 14 years Dr. Slagle has
been president of the Western
university. He was graduated
from Lafayette College in
1887, studied here from 1889
to 1892, and again in 1893-4,
and was subsequently professor of chemistry at the School
of Mines.

TWO NEW GAMES ON
JAY COURT SCHEDULE

Subject Announced

Dunlap Says Mouth
Is Most Expressive
A girl's mouth, and not her eyes,
will reveal the depth of her feelings,
romantic tradition notwithstanding,
according to the discoveries of Dr.
Knight Dunlap, professor of Psychology here, in the field of facial
expression.
Dr. Dunlap, by taking pictures
representing the usual emotions registered by the human countenance,
and cutting them so as to separate
the eyes from the nose and mouth,
was able to piece them together in
such a way that the eyes, supposed
to indlcte one feeling, readily
seemed to express another when
matched with a second mouth. The
mouth muscles remained the indices
to the emotions.

DR. LANCASTER PRESENTS FIRST OF
TEN VOLUMES ON FRENCH LITERATURE
Dr. H. Carrington Lancaster, professor of French Literature and
chairman of the Department of Romance Languages, announced that
the Johns Hopkins Press will publish the first two volumes of his latest work: "A History of French
Dramatic Literature in the Seventeenth Century." The set of books
in its entirety will comprise, Dr.
Lancaster said, probably ten volumes.
The first two volumes will have
the sub-title "The Pre-Classical
Period (1610-1634)," and although
they are in the process of being
printed, will not make their appearance before the beginning of the fall
term.

At the present time thete is no

Althought the books are titled as
covering the material from 1610 to
1634, there is an introductory chaper dealing with the subject from the
reign of Henry IV.
The book will be used by graduate
students and professors and is expected to provide an instructive
treatise upon the subject.

EASTERN SHORE
TRIP FRUITFUL
Musical Club Members Accorded
Gratifying Reception
PERFORMANCES IMPROVING
Club Performs Before Audiences
at Easton and Salisbury
Acclaimed by enthusiastic audiences in Easton and .Salisbury, the
Musical Club, on December 26 and
27, made a big success of its annual
Eastern Shore tour. Noticeable improvement in the quality of the
organization's performance marked
both concerts.
Accompanied by Mr. Conrad
Gebelein, director of the Banjo
Club, about 50 members left Homewood on Monday at 9 A. M. on two
buses and arrived in Salisbury at
3 p. m., having taken lunch en route
at Dover. At Salisbury the club occupied an entire floor of the Wicomico Hotel. The men were entertained in the afternoon at a tea
given by Mrs. Ruark and Mrs. Atkins, and a number were entertained
afterwards by friends.
Boynton on Vacation

I. Evans Rodgers was substituted
for Benny Boynton, who was home
on vacation. The former Barnstormer president was well received.
The Banjo Club was also particularly impressive in the presentation
at the Arcade Theater. The concert
was well attended, and the dance,
held afterwards at the hotel for the
benefit of a local hospital, was
crowded.
Tuesday, at 4 P. M., the club left
for Easton, and went directly to the
theater. Here the audience was not
only large, but very sympathetic.
The performance was benefited by
the previous night's experience; the
entire program received a more effective rendition. Particularly was
this noticed in the work of the Hawaiian group, which made a big
hit
with two additional numbers.

"The Student and the Social
Order" served as the general subject of the annual meeting of the
League of Industrial Democracy,
held at Columbia University, December 28-30.
The conference opened with a
symposium on -Present-day Capitalism in America," several prominent American economists taking
part. Sessions on the following day
were confined to informal discussion
groups on "Liberal Activities on the
Campus," "Education as a Road to
Freedom," "The Value of Political
Action" and "The Class Struggle
and Labor Unionism."
Among the prominent figures attending the league sessions were:
Ivy Lee, Prof. Harry F. Ward, Paul
Blonshard, Robert Morse Lovett,
William P. Hapgood, Norman
Thomas, Felix Cohen, United States
Senator Gerald P. Nye, Norman
Hapgood and Dr. Harry W. Laidler.

America Discovered for $7200
Old records show that the cost of Columbus' first
expedition to America amounted,in modern exchange,
to only $7200. To finance Columbus, Isabella,
Queen of Spain, offered to pawn her jewels. Today
word comes from Spain indicating that a twentieth
century importation from the new world is fast effecting a sufficient saving to ransom many royal jewels.
The Spanish Northern Railway reports that the
American equipment with which in 1924 the railroad
electrified a mountainous section of its lines from Ujo
to Pajares has accomplished the following economies:

The substations, overhead
equipment for the complete

installation, and six of the
twelve locomotives for this
particularly difficult and
successful electrification
were furnished by the General Electric Company. General Electric quality has
attained universal recognition; the world over, you
will find the G-E monogram
on apparatus that is giving
outstanding service.

1. A 55% saving in the cost of power.
2. A reduction of 40% in the number of engine miles for
the same traffic handled.
3. A saving of 7332% in the cost of repairs and upkeep
for locomotives.
4. A saving of 63% in crew expenses.
5. A reduction of 31% in the cost of moving a tonkilometer of freight.

In every part of the world, electricity has replaced
less efficient methods and is saving sums far
greater than the ransom of a queen's jewels. Xou
will always find it an important advantage in your
work and in your home.

VERNON SCHEIDT, '28
WILLIAM B. BANKS,'29

When the "New Plan" was announced as the definite policy
of this University, one of the revolutionary features of the
plan was the abandonment, in the near future, of the first two
years of collegiate instruction and the abolishment of the
College of Arts and Sciences. The student body would be
composed of only those students who sought a higher degree
than the Bachelor of Arts.
For various reasons, since the first enunciation of the plan,
the apparently fairly imminent abolition of the College of Arts
and Sciences has been placed in the category of an "ultimate
end." And more recently it has become more and more apparent that this part of the plan cannot become a reality for years
to come. Hopkins needs the undergraduate department. It is
hardly heresy to say, particularly, that the University needs
the income derived from the undergraduates' tuition fees.
This is an undisputed fact. Of course, it is conceivable that
some wealthy man or institution such as the General Educational Board might suddenly present the University with a
few million dollars, but we shall let you draw your own conclusions as to the probability of this..
For the past year the University has centered its attention
upon the New Plan. The undergraduate department has received little notice and considerable neglect. The list of courses
has been drastically cut, and many students are being subjected to high school pedagogical methods at the hands of
earnest and well-meaning, but green, student assistants.
The unfortunate situation that now exists was almost inevitable, however. The past year has been one of transition and
experiment, one in which the undergraduate department was
bound to suffer. The censure that has been passed upon the
administration by many of the students should, more rightfully, have been cast upon the existing circumstances.
Many members of the faculty realize that the College of
Arts and Sciences canot be abolished for some time to come.
They realize, moreover, that if this is the case, the undergraduates are deserving of more consideration than the catalogue accords them at present. Before the end of the year, we
have good reason to believe, several changes will take place
that will grant to the students in the College a wider range of
courses and a more satisfactory working basis generally. In
place of the two or three courses now being offered in any one
department, it is quite probable that a system will be inaugurated wherein five or six courses will be given, although in
alternate years. Such a plan would allow the departments
to keep within their budgets, but at the same time would
allow students to take more than two courses in any subject.
It is undoubtedly an improvement over the present scheme of
starvation.
Unless we are very much mistaken, the College next year
should be a much more satisfactory place to attend than it has
been so far this year. We do not strike this note of optimism
with any misgivings: We believe that the administration
realizes that certain conditions are unsatisfactory, and will
take steps, shortly, to remedy them.
